title: 111_hr5779
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Reduce and End our Deficits Using Commonsense Eliminations in the Agriculture Program Act". The table of contents for this Act is provided. Sec. 1. Short title; table of contents.
Sec. 2. Termination of Federal commodity storage payments for cotton and peanut producers.
Sec. 3. Termination of Forest Service Economic Action Program.
Sec. 4. Termination of grants to manufacturers of worsted wool fabrics.
Sec. 5. Termination of Department of Agriculture health care services program for the Delta region.
Sec. 6. Termination of energy efficiency grants and loans in rural communities with high energy costs.
Sec. 7. Revised income limitations for agricultural payments.
Sec. 8. New limits on payments to producers of certain agricultural commodities. Sec. 9-12: Reductions in payment acres for commodity programs, funding for market access program, reimbursement rate for private insurance companies under crop insurance program, and prohibition on timber sales in certain regions of the National Forest System. SEC. 2. Termination of federal commodity storage payments for cotton and peanut producers. Amendments made to sections in the Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008.
SEC. 3. Termination of Forest Service Economic Action Program providing assistance for rural economies through forest resources.
SEC. 4. Termination of grants to manufacturers of worsted wool fabrics.
SEC. 5. Termination of Department of Agriculture health care services program for the Delta region. Repeal of Section 379G of the Consolidated Farm and Rural Development Act. SEC. 6. Repeal of Section 379G of the Consolidated Farm and Rural Development Act and Section 19 of the Rural Electrification Act of 1936. SEC. 7. Revised adjusted gross income limitations for agricultural payments and benefits. The text chunk discusses amendments to income limitations for commodity programs and direct payments under the Food Security Act of 1985. The income limits vary for different crop years, with decreasing limits over time. Amendments to income limitations for commodity programs and direct payments under the Food Security Act of 1985 include declining limits over different crop years, with specific amounts set for each year. Amendments to income limitations for commodity programs and direct payments under the Food Security Act of 1985 include declining limits over different crop years, with specific amounts set for each year, such as $840,000 for 2012 and $750,000 for 2013 and subsequent years. SEC. 8. New limits on payments to producers of certain agricultural commodities. New limits on payments to producers of certain agricultural commodities have been amended to reduce direct payments from $40,000 to $20,000 and counter-cyclical payments from $65,000 to $32,500 for covered commodities. Similar reductions have been made for peanuts as well. The Food Security Act of 1985 has been amended to reduce counter-cyclical payments from $65,000 to $32,500 for covered commodities. SEC. 9. One percent reduction in payment acres for commodity programs. The Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008 is amended to define 'payment acres' for direct and counter-cyclical payments based on percentages of base acres for covered commodities on a farm. The Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008 is amended to define 'payment acres' for direct and counter-cyclical payments based on percentages of base acres for covered commodities on a farm, including peanuts. The Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008 defines 'payment acres' for direct and counter-cyclical payments based on percentages of base acres for covered commodities on a farm, including peanuts. For the 2012 crop year, 84 percent of the base acres of peanuts on a farm receive direct payments, and for each of the 2011 and 2012 crop years, 84 percent of the base acres of peanuts on a farm receive counter-cyclical payments. SEC. 10 amends the Agricultural Trade Act of 1978 to reduce funding for the Market Access Program. SEC. 11 reduces the reimbursement rate paid to private insurance companies under the Crop Insurance Program. Section 508(k) of the Federal Crop Insurance Act is amended to adjust the percentage of premium used to define loss ratio for different reinsurance years. Subparagraph (E) is removed and redesignated as subparagraph (D). PROHIBITION ON TIMBER SALES: The Secretary of Agriculture is prohibited from conducting timber sales in certain regions of the National Forest System where Federal expenditures exceed offsetting receipts until certifying to Congress that sales will generate enough receipts to cover expenses.
